d: The stupid monk recovers the stolen flocks.
r: Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 61; Alphabet No. 718; Mensa Philosophica No. 187.
a: A nobleman steals the abbot's flocks, saying that the monks have no use for them since they eat no meat. The most learned of the monks tries to recover them, but without success. The most stupid is then sent. Asked to dinner, he eats till he can hold no more. He tells the nobleman that he ate as much as possible since he could take back with him only what he had in his stomach. The nobleman pleased with the reply returns the flocks.

d: Simpleton's naive answer to robbers makes them think he knows their secret.

d: Mildness triumphs over violence: queen advises husband to use kindness to enemies.
a: This wins them over where war failed.

a: This causes pagan to repent. Conversion follows.

d: Sun cursed by man for its burning rays, wind for its hot breath, but moon is blessed for its soft, cool, and beautiful light.

a: Survives him and inherits property.

d: Priest who gives mild penances succeeds where others fail.

d: Mosquitoes sting King Pharaoh and show they are stronger than the man who cannot escape them.

a: Bride asks suitors what they have to offer her. Poor youth who has nothing but love to offer gets her.

d: Slow flying swan lasts longer than speedy crow in flying.
Frog, tortoise, fish each tell of how long they expect to live.
a: Frog alone does not expect to live to a hundred and ten years and alone escapes fisherman's net.

d: Proud king humbled: realizes that pomp, possessions, power are all of short duration.
King, defeated in battle, obliged to flee without money.
Boasting king insulted by crow dropping filth on him.
Defeated king must be peddler or beggar.
Queen forced to become a courtesan.

a: (King in the bath.) While the king is in the bath (or hunting) an angel in his form takes his place. The king is repulsed on all sides until he repents of his haughtiness.

d: Rich man made poor to punish pride.
r: Type 836; Irish: Beal XXI 336, O'Suilleabhain 122; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas II 249; India: Thompson-Balys.
a: He boasts that God has no power to make him poor. While he is at church, his property burns and he returns home poor.

d: Woman casts ring into sea boasting that it is as impossible for her to become poor as for the ring to be found.
r: W. Jones Finger-Ring Lore (London, 1898) 440; Finnish-Swedish: Wessman 19 No. 178.
a: Ring is found in fish: she becomes poor.

d: Proud inscriptions sole remains of powerful king.
r: *Chauvin V 33 No. 16; Spanish Exempla: Keller. Cf. Shelley's "Ozymandias".

d: King vainly forbids tide to rise.
a: (Canute.)

d: King vainly attempts to measure the height of the sky and the depth of the sea.
God punishes David for his pride in the number of his subjects.
a: An angel is sent to kill his people. Desists only when David repents.

d: King commanded to wear enemy's shoes on his shoulders as sign of submission.
Proud king humbled when imprisoned by enemies.
God finds that his statue sells at low price.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 80 (ET 455), 94 (ST 77); Halm Aesop No. 137.
a: He prices it in a statue shop and finds that his price is lower than other gods.

d: King shown he is less powerful than God.
a: In spite of all his plans, his servant recovers the lost (exchanged) treasure.
Both served up at same meal.
Man sets self up as a god.

d: Attempt to fly to heaven punished.
a: Car supported by eagles.

d: Attempt to climb to heaven punished.
Peter acts as God for a day: tires of bargain.
a: A girl takes her goat to pasture and leaves him: "My God care for you! " Peter must run everywhere after the goat.

d: Man who has never known unhappiness or want is swallowed up by earth with all his household.
Dream (prophecy) of future greatness causes banishment (imprisonment).
Poor man aspires to high office: made a cook.
Arrogant mistress repaid in kind by her lover.
r: *Type 900; *BP I 443ff.; **Philippson Ktsnig Drosselbart FFC L; Krappe Itudes ital.

d: Haughty mistress makes extravagant demands of lover: repaid.

a: (Glove and the Lion.)

d: Scorned lover poses as rich man and cheats his scornful mistress.
r: Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 10 (Lee 266); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Sneering princess is impregnated by magic.

a: He has formerly refused this man charity.

d: Cruel brothers brought to beg charity from abused sister.
Impoverished father begs from daughter he has banished: recognized.
Impoverished father begs from his prosperous daughter whom he has made to marry a poor man.
Impoverished husband begs from wife he has formerly expelled.
Impoverished youngest brother comes to elders in search of work.
Arrogant farmer allows none to ride his precious horse without permission.
a: He kills the man who does it, but is in revenge deprived of most of his goods.

r: *Types 756A, 756B; BP III 463ff.; *Andrejev FFC LXIX 160ff., 250ff.; Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 21 No. 16; Alphabet No. 206; Irish: O'Suilleabhain 99, Beal XXI 332; Spanish: Espinosa II Nos 79f.
a: He has said of a condemned man that he deserves his punishment.
Abbot tells him to search his own heart to see if he is free of sin before attacking others.
She has passed judgment on a girl who has a bastard.

d: Woman with three hundred sixty-five children.
r: *Taylor Notes and Queries No. 251 (Feb., 1923) 96; *K. Nyrop Grevinden med de 365 Born (Kshbenhavn, 1909); Zs. f. Vksk.
a: Punished for self-righteous condemnation of unchaste girl.

r: *Type 800; BP I 342; Wesselski Bebel I 126 No. 19.
a: Throws God's footstool at an old woman thief on earth.

d: The beggar on the cross in place of Christ.
a: Is made to leave the cross for his impatience concerning the sinners.

d: Proud animal less fortunate than humble.
Wild animal finds his liberty better than tame animal's ease.

a: The tame bird tells the wild one to look about him. He is shot.

d: Wild ass envies tame ass until he sees his burdens.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 59 (ST 198), 124 (ST 328); Halm Aesop No. 321.

d: Wolf prefers liberty and hunger to dog's servitude and plenty.
r: *Type 201; Crane Vitry 221 No. 217; Wienert FFC LVI 61 (ET 238), 124 (ST 326); Halm Aesop No. 278; Jacobs Aesop 206 No. 28; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 433; Scala Celi 76b No. 435; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Parrot prefers cold wet nest in freedom to luxury in royal palace.
Ass is jealous of the horse until he learns better.
Ass jealous of horse, but sees horse later working in a mill.
Ass jealous of war-horse until he sees him wounded.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 58 (ET 191), 124 (ST 327); Halm Aesop No. 328; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Mule carrying corn escapes while one carrying gold is robbed.
Lean dogs envy arena-dog his fatness.
a: Later see their error.

d: Calf pities draft ox: is taken to slaughter, ox spared.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 61 (ET 230), 57 (ET 185), *92 (ST 44), 124 (ST 331); Halm Aesop No. 113.

d: Stag scorns his legs but is proud of his horns.
r: *Type 77; Wienert FFC LVI 65 (ET 285), 140 (ST 465); Halm Aesop No. 128; *Crane Vitry 254 No. 274; Herbert III 23; Jacobs Aesop 206 No. 25.
a: Caught by his horns in trees.

d: Fox destroys nest of bird who boasts of nest's warmth.

r: " Wienert FFC LVI 64 (ET 275), 94 (ST 80); Halm Aesop No. 157.
a: When well fed says, "My mother was a thoroughbred horse. " Later, hard worked, says, "My father was a miserable ass.

d: The man scorns the storm: killed by it.
Zeus smites Capaneus while he is climbing a ladder.
Pride or wealth of man brought low by actions of gods.
Oil lamp blown out: had thought that it outshone stars.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 75 (ET 409), 93 (ST 64); Halm Aesop No. 285.

d: Jackal singing about his deeds falls down from tree and is eaten by alligator.
Gnats having overcome lion are in turn killed by spider.
r: Wienert FFC LVI 48 (ET 75), 92 (ST 57); Halm Aesop No. 234.

d: Men too prosperous (happy): things are made more difficult.
Men are too rich: greedy gods created to impoverish them.
Men are too rich: gold sent below ground.
Men are too rich: weeds created to spoil their harvests.
Men are too proud: snakes created.
Men are fearless: tiger made to frighten them.
Men enjoy themselves too much: disease created.
